summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of a Lieutenant at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the events surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019. The Lieutenant details standard operating procedures, the discovery of Epstein's body, and reveals that the two Corrections Officers on duty admitted to not conducting required rounds and that Epstein did not have a required cellmate.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found deceased in his cell at MCC on August 10, 2019. He was housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) and had previously been on suicide watch.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: The interviewee, a supervisor at MCC with 17 years of service. He discovered the emergency, responded to Epstein's cell, administered CPR, and investigated the circumstances with the officers on duty.

persons.name: Officer Noel
persons.context: One of the two COs present at Epstein's cell when he was found. She stated 'EPSTEIN hung himself' and admitted to not conducting the 3:00am and 5:00am rounds. She did not write a memo about the incident and has not returned to work since.

persons.name: Officer Thomas
persons.context: One of the two COs present, who was attempting to administer CPR when the Lieutenant arrived. He was distraught, left MCC without writing a memo, and has not returned to work since the incident.

persons.name: Lieutenant Cannata
persons.context: The Lieutenant who worked the shift prior to the interviewee on August 9-10, 2019. The log of inmate movements from his shift should have indicated if Epstein's cellmate was removed.

persons.name: FBI Special Agent
persons.context: One of the FBI agents who conducted the interview of the MCC Lieutenant.

persons.name: FBI Special Agent Kuhrt
persons.context: One of the FBI agents who conducted the interview and witnessed the signing of the OIG warnings form.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: An AUSA who was present during the FBI interview of the MCC Lieutenant.

persons.name: Office of the Inspector General Special Agent
persons.context: An OIG Special Agent who was present during the interview.

persons.name: Duty Nurse
persons.context: MCC medical personnel who arrived at Epstein's cell and took over administering CPR, and later removed Epstein's body.

connections.description: Both were Corrections Officers on duty in the SHU on the night of Epstein's death and were together at his cell when he was found.
Noel was one of the officers responsible for monitoring Epstein's cell. She admitted to not conducting required rounds.
Thomas was one of the officers responsible for monitoring Epstein's cell and was attempting CPR when the Lieutenant arrived.
The Lieutenant is a GS-11 supervisor; Officer Noel is a Corrections Officer under his supervision. He advised her to document the incident truthfully.
Both are GS-11 Lieutenants at MCC. Cannata worked the shift immediately prior to the interviewee on the night of Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was first placed on suicide watch at MCC.

events.title: Day Before Death
events.description: The interviewed Lieutenant did not work. Lieutenant Cannata was on duty.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's Death
events.description: At approximately 6:33am, a medical emergency was called from the 9th floor SHU. The Lieutenant responded and found Epstein unresponsive in his cell with Officers Noel and Thomas present. A noose made of bedsheets was observed. Epstein was pronounced dead.

events.title: Admission of Missed Rounds
events.description: Officers Noel and Thomas admitted to the Lieutenant that they did not conduct the required 3:00am and 5:00am inmate count rounds.

events.title: FBI Interview of MCC Lieutenant
events.description: The Lieutenant was interviewed by FBI Special Agents, an OIG Special Agent, and an AUSA regarding Epstein's death and MCC procedures.
personsInvolved: Office of the Inspector General Special Agent

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, New York
FBI-New York offices, 290 Broadway, New York, New York
keyFacts: Corrections Officers Noel and Thomas admitted to not conducting the mandatory 3:00am and 5:00am inmate count rounds on the night Jeffrey Epstein died.
Jeffrey Epstein did not have a cellmate ('bunkie') at the time of his death, which violated standard MCC policy requiring inmates on suicide watch or psychological observation to have one.
Officers Noel and Thomas left MCC without filing required memos about the incident and had not returned to work as of the interview date.
The Lieutenant confirmed that if count rounds were not done, the associated count slips would have been falsified if they were signed.
MCC policy required a log of daily inmate movements to be passed between shifts; the log from Lieutenant Cannata's shift should have indicated if Epstein's cellmate was removed.
